content.webTitle: Salford hit their stride in eight-try romp against stunned St Helens

fields.headline: Salford hit their stride in eight-try romp against stunned St Helens
fields.bodyText: Not only is it almost a year to the day since Salford were hammered 52-6 by St Helens in round two of Super League but that was the result that prompted the club’s flamboyant owner, Marwan Koukash, to cause panic among their supporters by simply tweeting: “I have had enough.” The irony cannot be lost on Salford fans. It was a tweet that meant little but you suspect Koukash’s social media offerings after Thursday night’s match will be slightly more complimentary. He walked out of the fixture early 12 months ago but after this performance – spearheaded by the outstanding half-back Robert Lui – Koukash must have been keen to stay and celebrate all night. It is only round two but this was arguably the finest Salford performance since he assumed control of the club three years ago – and certainly the best since Ian Watson took charge as the coach midway through last season. Lui, the former North Queensland half-back who arrived in Super League with a considerable reputation, will grab most of the headlines after his two tries but this was as rounded a team performance as you are likely to see. “Robert is obviously a very good player,” Watson said afterwards. “However, our middle men really stood up which allowed Robert and Michael [Dobson] to play. There’s been some questions thrown our way but the belief we showed was exceptional.” This was far from ideal preparation for next week’s World Club Series for Saints. Had Sydney Roosters, their opponents in the three-match tournament, stayed up late in Dubai to watch this performance, they would have been wishing the game was tomorrow. “You could smell an air of complacency about the lads before the game,” said the St Helens coach, Keiron Cunningham. “I spoke to the staff about it but once they cross the line, you can’t do anything.” Already without the injured hooker James Roby, Saints’ problems were compounded with another for the in-form centre Mark Percival that Cunningham said “doesn’t look good”. By the time Percival was withdrawn midway through the second half, though, the game was over. A superb kick from Lui’s half-back partner Dobson set the tone as he found Greg Johnson unmarked in the corner to break the deadlock and from there Salford never let up. They were 18-0 up after 12 minutes following tries for Craig Kocpzak and another from Lui before the visitors offered a brief response with an Alex Walmsley try. Luke Walsh was sent to the sin-bin on the half-hour and that allowed Salford the chance to kill off the game and tries from Niall Evalds and a second from Lui, both of which followed rampaging breaks from the winger Justin Carney, put them out of sight by the interval. Carney in particular was a sight to behold, looking every inch the winger he was at Castleford, terrorising the Saints defence almost every time he touched the ball. The second half was slightly more tolerable for Saints but the damage had long since been done. Adam Swift managed a consolation but tries from Adam Walne, an outstanding solo score from Dobson and a second for Evalds rubber-stamped a remarkable match for the Red Devils. Salford O’Brien; Carney, Jones, J Griffin, Johnson; Lui, Dobson; Kopczak, Lee, G Griffin, Murdoch-Masila, Flanagan, Lannon. Interchange Evalds, Walne, Tomkins, Joseph. Tries Johnson, Kopczak, Lui 2, Evalds 2, Walne, Dobson. Goals J Griffin 2, Dobson 4. St Helens Owens; Makinson, McCarthy-Scarsbrook, Percival, Swift; Turner, Walsh; Amor, Knowles, Tasi, Vea, Wilkin, Thompson. Interchange Walmsley, Richards, Savelio, Fages. Tries Walmsley, Swift. Goal Walsh. Referee R Silverwood. Attendance 4,386.
